content.description: Two students wish to determine the value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the acceleration due to gravity at Earth’s surface. The students have a collection of blocks of different masses, a string of negligible mass, a pulley of negligible mass, and a device for measuring acceleration. The students attach two of the blocks to the ends of the string and pass the string over the pulley so the blocks hang vertically on either side. The blocks are then released from rest, and their acceleration is measured. The students’ data for one trial are shown below, with <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> equal to the masses of the blocks. Considering the gravitational forces acting on the blocks, do the data provide a reasonable determination of the value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and what is a possible justification for why or why not?
content.question: <math alttext="m sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (grams) <math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="m sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> (grams) <math alttext="600" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>600</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="a, in meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi><mtext> </mtext><mtext> </mtext><mrow><mo>(</mo><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>m</mi><mo>/</mo><msup><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mstyle><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="1.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

choices.label: Yes, because the value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> may be calculated by applying Newton’s second law and using the gravitational forces to determine the net force on the blocks-string system.

Yes, because the value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> may be calculated by applying Newton’s third law and using the gravitational forces as an action-reaction force pair.
No, because the blocks’ acceleration has a magnitude significantly less than <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

No, because the calculated value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is too small, possibly due to an additional force exerted on the blocks-string system.

content.answer: No, because the calculated value of <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is too small, possibly due to an additional force exerted on the blocks-string system.
